page.title: 06ECOLOGY OF TYSOE - 1
page.content: The area surrounding Tysoe is typical South Warwickshire countryside with hawthorn hedges and oak, ash, and sycamore trees. There are no elm trees left since Dutch Elm Disease destroyed them several years ago. To offset this farmers have been encouraged to plant trees in corners of fields and areas where cultivation is difficult. The trees on the ridge from Sunrising to Old Lodge were planted in the early 1960's and are mainly conifers. Footpaths are little used except the ones between Lower and Middle Tysoe and one to the Windmill from Upper Tysoe. Wild life in the area includes badgers, foxes, and rabbits on the hill, weasels and stoats. Muntjac and fallow deer have been seen but are rare.
